summary: A DIY project video featuring Pengu, who introduces a homemade telescope setup used to capture the 2015 lunar eclipse.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a cartoon penguin character holding a soldering iron and a wrench, standing against a gray background. The penguin is wearing a bone on its head and a yellow spotted apron. Above the penguin, the text "www.HomoFaciens.de presents: 'Lunar eclipse 2015'" is displayed in blue and black fonts, indicating the theme of the video. The scene then transitions to a close-up of the moon, showing a partial lunar eclipse with the moon's surface partially covered by Earth's shadow. The moon's craters and surface details are visible against the dark background of space. The video then shifts to a close-up of a camera lens with a circuit board attached to it, featuring various electronic components and wires. The camera lens is mounted on a tripod, and the background is a plain gray surface. The video concludes with a wider shot of the camera lens and tripod, showing the entire setup in more detail.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker expressing surprise about the early timing of a lunar eclipse in 2015. He then describes connecting a camera module to a zoom lens to capture the astronomical event. The clip ends with a single brief, distinct "click" sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up shot of a black circular object and a green circuit board with a camera module attached, placed on a white surface. The camera module is connected to the circuit board via a white ribbon cable. The scene then transitions to a different angle, showing a pair of pliers holding the camera module, with a person's hand visible in the background. The person uses a white tool to adjust the camera module, ensuring it is securely attached to the circuit board. The video focuses on the detailed process of handling and adjusting the camera module, highlighting the precision required in the task. The background remains consistent throughout, with a plain white surface providing a clean and uncluttered workspace.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker explains that for the linkage, the rear plastic cover of a lens has to be surface ground and drilled with an 8 mm center hole. He then says that the lens of the camera module has to be removed. He describes placing the camera board on a flat surface and using a piece of depron as a bedding layer, and keeping it in place with a caliper. The speaker then describes using a stick of cold hot glue to press on the lens and unscrew it, or using a pencil with a rubber at the rear end. There is a brief sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a small electronic circuit board with a ribbon cable attached, placed on a black circular object with adhesive residue. The scene transitions to a camera lens with a green arrow indicating the direction of focus adjustment. The next frame shows a close-up of the lens's focus ring with a green double-headed arrow, emphasizing the movement. Following this, a black lens adapter labeled "20mm" is displayed on a white surface. The video then shows a camera lens with an electronic circuit board attached to its body, connected by blue wires, mounted on a tripod. The final frame focuses on the lens's focus ring with a green double-headed arrow, highlighting the adjustment mechanism. Throughout the video, the background remains neutral, and the camera provides clear, detailed views of the objects and their features.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a calm, male voice explaining "how you can use some hot glue at the corners of the board to mount the camera module on the plastic cover". He transitions to discussing "the flange focal distance" and how "the length between the rear of the lens to the plane of the light sensitive chip has to be considered to record focused images". He continues, describing how he "tried several spacers and found that with 20 millimeters, best", before concluding that "it's no perfect solution, but on the afternoon before the event, it was the best camera adapter I could create". Following this, a low-frequency hum becomes audible and remains present until the end of the clip.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a close-up of a black camera lens mounted on a tripod, with a small electronic device attached to its side, connected by blue wires. The background is a plain, neutral gray, emphasizing the camera setup. A hand appears, pointing towards the electronic device, indicating its significance. The camera then shifts to a different angle, focusing on the camera body and lens, highlighting the intricate details and the connection between the lens and the electronic device. The video maintains a consistent focus on the camera setup, with no significant changes in the environment or background.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker stating that a "reasonably priced tripod is also no good solution for astronomical observations", delivered in a neutral tone. This transitions into another male speaker stating "as you can see, you get enormous clearance for your money" in a conversational tone. A sound then occurs that could be characterized as a clanking or metallic noise, abruptly ending the clip.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a person's hands holding a black camera with a large lens attached, positioned on a tripod. The person is seen adjusting the camera, focusing on the lens and the camera body. The background is a plain, light-colored surface, providing a neutral backdrop that highlights the camera and the person's hands. The person's hands are shown in detail, with fingers gripping the camera body and lens, indicating a careful and deliberate adjustment process. The camera is then shown without the lens attached, revealing the camera's mount and the lens mount's interior. The video then transitions to a close-up of a Raspberry Pi camera module, labeled "Raspberry Pi Camera Rev.1.3," with a ribbon cable attached. The camera module is shown in detail, highlighting its components and the text on the circuit board. The background remains a plain, light-colored surface, maintaining consistency with the previous scene. The video concludes with a focus on the camera module, emphasizing its design and the text on the circuit board, providing a clear view of the Raspberry Pi camera's features.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker mentioning that "The Raspberry Camera can't control the aperture or the lens". He then adds that "to get an aperture of less than four", the lens can be removed while the aperture is triggered. Following this, the speaker describes how "the light sensor used with the Raspberry Pi camera module is clearly smaller than that of a standard camera".

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up view of a Raspberry Pi camera module, showcasing its intricate details, including the sensor, circuit board, and various components labeled with text such as "PSV04A SUNNY" and "Raspberry Pi Camera." The camera module is mounted on a green circuit board with visible soldering points and printed text, including "1368MLB 9194V-0 MULTI 1 13 45." The scene then transitions to a clear, detailed image of the moon against a black background, highlighting its craters and surface features. The moon remains the central focus, with no significant changes in its appearance or the surrounding environment. The video maintains a steady view of the moon, emphasizing its texture and details, with no additional objects or text appearing on the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a speaker, a male, stating that a "crop factor of approximately nine" is achieved, leading to a "focal length of this zoom lens" reaching "up to 2,700 millimeters" in a factual tone. He then describes getting "a total view of the moon" when the zoom is adjusted to approximately 130 millimeters, which equals 1,200 millimeters with a Raspberry camera module.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a close-up view of the moon against a dark, starless sky. The moon's surface is detailed, with visible craters and maria, which are the darker, smoother areas. The moon appears to be in a waxing gibbous phase, with a slight shadow creeping over its left side, indicating the moon's movement through its phases. The shadow gradually increases, covering more of the moon's surface, suggesting the passage of time. The video captures the moon's serene and majestic presence in the night sky, emphasizing its natural beauty and the subtle changes in its appearance as it progresses through its lunar cycle.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker with a thoughtful and slightly critical tone, discussing the challenges of using a home-built telescope to observe the moon. He acknowledges the surprisingly good results given the simple construction, but notes its limitations. He mentions the moon's movement and the difficulty of tracking it with a cheap tripod. The speaker notes when a lunar eclipse started. Finally the speech fades away.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a close-up view of the moon against a dark, starless sky. The moon is partially illuminated, with the right side brightly lit and the left side in shadow, creating a crescent shape. The surface of the moon is detailed, showing various craters and maria, which are the darker, smoother areas. The video maintains a steady focus on the moon, capturing its gradual movement across the sky. The atmosphere is serene and tranquil, emphasizing the natural beauty of the lunar landscape.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker asking a question about the movement of Earth's shadow. The speaker continues in an informative tone, describing the moon's orbit and its distances from Earth. The speech concludes with "and," followed by what sounds like background music with an indistinct style or purpose.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a close-up view of the moon against a dark, starless sky. The moon appears in its waxing gibbous phase, with a significant portion illuminated by sunlight, while the rest remains in shadow. The surface of the moon is detailed, revealing various craters and maria, which are the darker, flat areas formed by ancient volcanic eruptions. The video captures the gradual movement of the moon, with the illuminated portion slowly shifting, indicating the passage of time. The atmosphere is serene and tranquil, emphasizing the natural beauty of the lunar landscape. The video does not feature any people, objects, or text, focusing solely on the moon's visual transformation.
events_list.audio_caption: A male voice provides context about the distance of the moon during a lunar eclipse, noting it was very close to the smallest possible separation. He also mentions the average separation between Earth and Moon increases each year. He then says "The moon is nippled by the Earth's Umbra." He follows with something unintelligible.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a close-up view of the moon against a dark, starless sky. The moon is partially illuminated, with the right side brightly lit and the left side in shadow, creating a crescent shape. The surface of the moon is detailed, showing various craters and maria, which are the darker, smoother areas. The video maintains a steady focus on the moon, with no visible movement or change in the environment. The atmosphere is calm and serene, emphasizing the natural beauty of the lunar surface.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker discussing the recording of a sequence at "15 minutes past 3." He then describes the contrast of the video images being too low, making it difficult to see the reddish part of the moon's surface shadowed by the earth. He mentions recording the sequences with an aperture of 11, an exposure time of 25 milliseconds set with the software parameter "shutter speed," and setting the light sensitivity to ISO 100 to reduce image noise.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a close-up view of the moon against a dark, starless sky. The moon appears in a crescent phase, with its illuminated portion on the right side, showcasing its craters and surface details. The background remains consistently dark, emphasizing the moon's presence. Throughout the video, there are no visible changes in the moon's position, phase, or the surrounding environment, maintaining a static and serene atmosphere.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker stating the third sequence was recorded at a specific time, then describing how the moon was covered by the Earth's umbra after about 30 minutes. The speaker continues, explaining that the next sequences appear "rickety" because he opened a window to follow the moon's movement, which caused optical distortions as warm air escaped.

events_list.video_caption: The video captures a serene night sky, showcasing a crescent moon in various stages of illumination. The moon's surface is detailed with craters and shadows, creating a textured appearance. As the video progresses, the moon appears to move slightly, revealing more of its illuminated side. The background remains consistently dark, emphasizing the moon's glow against the night sky. The atmosphere is calm and tranquil, with no visible people or objects, focusing solely on the celestial body. The visual changes highlight the moon's gradual transition from a partially lit crescent to a more fully illuminated crescent, showcasing the natural beauty of the night sky.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a calm male voice stating scientific facts about the Moon orbiting the Earth and its mass relative to Earth. The tone is informative and measured. The speaker then describes the shape of the illuminated surface as a "narrow crescent." He admits failing to record the moon's surface in the Earth's umbra, mentioning appropriate values for light sensitivity, aperture, and exposure time. He concludes that he needs to upgrade his equipment for the next lunar eclipse. The clip ends abruptly with the sound of electronic static.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a dark scene featuring a crescent moon in the night sky. The moon is partially illuminated, with the right side showing a bright crescent shape against the black background. As the video progresses, the moon becomes more visible, revealing more of its surface and details. The moon's illuminated portion gradually increases, showing a larger crescent shape. The background remains consistently dark, emphasizing the moon's presence. The video concludes with the moon appearing as a larger crescent, with more of its surface visible and illuminated, showcasing the moon's craters and texture. The overall atmosphere is serene and focused on the moon's gradual illumination against the night sky.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker, calmly explaining that "just a small fraction of the moon surface is still outside the Earth's umbra" and later noting, "the moon starts leaving the umbra". The speaker then observes that "the celestial object is above the roofs of my small hometown from my point of view."

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a close-up view of the moon against a dark, starless sky. The moon is in a waxing crescent phase, with the illuminated portion gradually increasing in size. The surface of the moon is detailed, revealing craters and maria, which are the darker, flat areas. The video captures the moon's subtle movements as it rotates, providing a clear view of its changing phases. The background remains consistently dark, emphasizing the moon's brightness and the contrast between the illuminated and shadowed areas. The video focuses solely on the moon, with no other objects or text present, creating a serene and tranquil atmosphere.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing how the temperature dropped and caused convection, also mentioning the moon's proximity to the Earth's horizon and the visibility of the moon's scintillation. The speaker continues, stating, "the more the moon exits the umbra of the Earth, the more you notice the scintillation." He then indicates that the sequence was recorded at a certain time. The speaker then shares their observation point coordinates and that the times are given in Central European Summer Time, which is plus two hours from Universal Time Code.

events_list.video_caption: The video captures a close-up view of the moon against a dark sky, showcasing its detailed surface with craters and shadows. As the video progresses, a thin, reddish-brown contrail from an airplane appears, cutting across the moon's surface. The airplane itself is visible as a small silhouette moving along the contrail, creating a striking visual effect. The moon remains the central focus throughout, with the airplane and its contrail adding a dynamic element to the otherwise static celestial scene. The video maintains a consistent atmosphere, emphasizing the contrast between the natural beauty of the moon and the man-made presence of the airplane.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker notes that it's 10 minutes past 6, and more than half of the moon's surface is visible. A plane then passes into view. The speaker adds that Frankfurt Airport is only 80 kilometers away.  The speaker notes that the plane is moving horizontally rather than climbing. The speaker then discusses that he turned the telescope on the tripod in order to capture a video of the moon as it moves horizontally across the screen. He says that it is hard to adjust the tripod to track the moon. The speaker goes on to say that the moon is also moving vertically towards the Earth's horizon. He concludes that he is able to see the Earth's shadow on the bottom right of the moon.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up view of the moon, showcasing its detailed surface with various craters and dark patches against a black background. The moon appears to be in a waxing gibbous phase, with the right side illuminated and the left side gradually darkening. The camera remains steady, focusing on the moon's surface features, such as the prominent dark areas known as lunar maria. The scene then transitions to a text overlay on a gray background, providing information about the project. The text reads: "You can find more information about the stuff shown in this video and things concerning science and technology at the homepage of the project: www.HomoFaciens.de." This text is in English, with the website URL highlighted in blue, directing viewers to the project's homepage for additional details. The video maintains a static presentation, emphasizing the moon's surface and the informative text without any dynamic movements or changes in the environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker saying, "At 20 minutes past six, the last but one sequence was recorded." He continues in a similar tone, describing recording the moon and plans to improve equipment, noting "preferably with better results." He mentions the next total lunar eclipse visible from his hometown will occur in July 2018, giving "adequate setup time." The next recorded sequence was at "26 minutes past six", which he follows by explaining that "The moon leaves the umbra" and that the eclipse ended at 27 minutes past six. He informs listeners that "You can get the built instruction of my telescope on the project page." He signs off saying, "Thanks for watching and I'll be back."
